hints.label: thm-sn-symmetry-n-particle
hints.title: S_N Permutation Symmetry (N-Particle)
hints.content:
671: :label: thm-sn-symmetry-n-particle
672: 
673: The N-particle transition operator $\Psi: \Sigma_N \to \mathcal{P}(\Sigma_N)$ is **S_N-equivariant**:
674: 
675: $$
676: \Psi(\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S}, \cdot) = (\sigma \cdot)_* \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot)
677: $$
678: 
679: for all $\sigma \in S_N$, where $\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S} = (w_{\sigma(1)}, \ldots, w_{\sigma(N)})$.
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-19
hints.title: Gauge Redundancy vs. Physical Symmetry
hints.content:
685: :class: important
686: 
687: The S_N symmetry reflects a **gauge redundancy** rather than a physical transformation:
688: 
689: - Relabeling walkers $1 \leftrightarrow 2$ does not change the physics
690: - The physically meaningful object is the **orbit** $[\mathcal{S}] = \{\sigma \cdot \mathcal{S} : \sigma \in S_N\}$
691: - This led to the orbifold structure $\mathcal{M}_{\text{config}} = \Sigma_N / S_N$ in {prf:ref}`thm-config-orbifold`

hints.label: def-empirical-measure-marginals
hints.title: Empirical Measure and Marginals
hints.content:
701: :label: def-empirical-measure-marginals
702: 
703: For an N-particle configuration $\mathcal{S} = (z_1, \ldots, z_N)$ with $z_i = (x_i, v_i)$, the **empirical measure** is:
704: 
705: $$
706: f^N(\mathcal{S}) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta_{z_i}
707: $$
708: 
709: The **k-particle marginal** of a probability measure $\nu_N$ on $\Sigma_N$ is:
710: 
711: $$
712: \mu_N^{(k)}(z_1, \ldots, z_k) = \int_{\Omega^{N-k}} \nu_N(z_1, \ldots, z_N) dz_{k+1} \cdots dz_N
713: $$
714: 
715: **Marginal hierarchy:**
716: 
717: $$
718: \mu_N^{(k)} \rightharpoonup \rho_0^{\otimes k} \quad \text{as } N \to \infty
719: $$
hints.raw_directive:
698: The connection between N-particle and mean-field descriptions is through the **BBGKY hierarchy**.
699: 
700: :::{prf:definition} Empirical Measure and Marginals
701: :label: def-empirical-measure-marginals
702: 
703: For an N-particle configuration $\mathcal{S} = (z_1, \ldots, z_N)$ with $z_i = (x_i, v_i)$, the **empirical measure** is:

707: $$
708:

710: 
711: $$
712: \mu_N^{(k)}(z_1, \ldots, z_k) = \int_{\Omega^{N-k}} \nu_N(z_1, \ldots, z_N) dz_{k+1} \cdots dz_N
713: $$
714: 
715: **Marginal hierarchy:**
716: 
717: $$
718: \mu_N^{(k)} \rightharpoonup \rho_0^{\otimes k} \quad \text{as } N \to \infty
719: $$

hints.label: thm-molecular-chaos-sn
hints.title: Molecular Chaos and S_N Symmetry
hints.content:
725: :label: thm-molecular-chaos-sn
726: 
727: The **molecular chaos assumption** (factorization of marginals) is a direct consequence of S_N symmetry in the thermodynamic limit.
728: 
729: **Statement:**
730: 
731: If $\nu_N$ is an S_N-invariant probability measure on $\Sigma_N$ (i.e., $\nu_N(\sigma \cdot A) = \nu_N(A)$ for all Borel sets $A$ and $\sigma \in S_N$), and if the empirical measures $f^N$ converge weakly to a limit $\rho_0$:
732: 
733: $$
734: f^N \rightharpoonup \rho_0 \quad \text{as } N \to \infty
735: $$
736: 
737: then the k-particle marginals **factorize**:
738: 
739: $$
740: \lim_{N \to \infty} \mu_N^{(k)}(z_1, \ldots, z_k) = \rho_0(z_1) \cdots \rho_0(z_k)
741: $$
742: 
743: **Interpretation:** In the limit, particles become **statistically independent** and **identically distributed** (i.i.d.) according to $\rho_0$.
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-83
hints.content:
747: 
748: :::{prf:proof}
749: **Sketch:**
750: 
751: 1. **Exchangeability from S_N:** S_N-invariance of $\nu_N$ implies that $\mu_N^{(k)}$ is **exchangeable** (permutation-symmetric in its arguments).
752: 
753: 2. **De Finetti's Theorem:** For an exchangeable sequence of random variables (the particle states), the joint distribution is a **mixture of i.i.d. distributions**:
754: 
755: $$
756: \mu_N^{(k)} = \int_{\mathcal{P}(\Omega)} \rho^{\otimes k} d\Pi_N(\rho)
757: $$
758: 
759: where $\Pi_N$ is a measure on the space of probability measures.
760: 
761: 3. **Convergence of empirical measure:** If $f^N \rightharpoonup \rho_0$, then $\Pi_N \rightharpoonup \delta_{\rho_0}$ (concentration at $\rho_0$).
762: 
763: 4. **Factorization:** Taking the limit:
764: 
765: $$
766: \lim_{N \to \infty} \mu_N^{(k)} = \int_{\mathcal{P}(\Omega)} \rho^{\otimes k} d\delta_{\rho_0}(\rho) = \rho_0^{\otimes k}
767: $$

hints.label: thm-gauge-mf-limit
hints.title: Gauge Structure in the Mean-Field Limit
hints.content:
775: :label: thm-gauge-mf-limit
776: 
777: In the mean-field limit $N \to \infty$:
778: 
779: 1. **Particle labels disappear:** The density $f(z, t)$ does not "remember" which particle is which. There is no notion of "walker $i$" anymore.
780: 
781: 2. **S_N becomes trivial:** The action of $S_N$ on the density is:
782: 
783: $$
784: \sigma_* f(z) = f(z) \quad \text{for all } \sigma \in S_N
785: $$
786: 
787: because $f$ is already averaged over all permutations.
788: 
789: 3. **Indistinguishability is intrinsic:** The "gauge symmetry" in the mean-field is the fact that $f(z)$ describes a **continuum** of indistinguishable particles. Any "relabeling" of infinitesimal parcels of probability mass leaves the physics invariant.
hints.raw_directive:
772: ### 4.3. From S_N to Intrinsic Indistinguishability
773: 
774: :::{prf:theorem} Gauge Structure in the Mean-Field Limit
775: :label: thm-gauge-mf-limit
776: 
777: In the mean-field limit $N \to \infty$:
778: 
779: 1. **Particle labels disappear:** The density $f(z, t)$ does not "remember" which particle is which. There is no notion of "walker $i$" anymore.
780: 
781: 2. **S_N becomes trivial:** The action of $S_N$ on the density is:
782: 
783: $$
784: \sigma_* f(z) = f(z) \quad \text{for all } \sigma \in S_N
785: $$
786: 
787: because $f$ is already averaged over all permutations.
788: 
789: 3. **Indistinguishability is intrinsic:** The "gauge symmetry" in the mean-field is the fact that $f(z)$ describes a **continuum** of indistinguishable particles. Any "relabeling" of infinitesimal parcels of probability mass leaves the physics invariant.

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-129
hints.title: Mathematical Formalization
hints.content:
795: :class: note
796: 
797: The "gauge symmetry" of the mean-field density is more accurately described as a **redundancy in the measure-theoretic description**:
798: 
799: - The density $f(z)$ is defined up to a **diffeomorphism** $\phi: \Omega \to \Omega$ that preserves the measure:
800: 
801: $$
802: f \sim \phi_* f \quad \text{if } \phi_* f = f
803: $$
804: 
805: - The space of such transformations forms the **diffeomorphism group** $\text{Diff}(\Omega, \mu)$ preserving the reference measure $\mu$.
806: 
807: - For the McKean-Vlasov equation, the "true" configuration space is the **orbit space** under this action:
808: 
809: $$
810: \mathcal{M}_{\text{config}}^{MF} = \mathcal{F} / \text{Diff}(\Omega, \mu)
811: $$
812: 
813: **This is an infinite-dimensional quotient**, far more complex than the $S_N$ quotient.
814: 
815: A rigorous treatment requires:
816: - Functional analysis on diffeomorphism groups (Arnold, Marsden, Ratiu)
817: - Geometric hydrodynamics (Otto calculus, Wasserstein geometry)

hints.label: prop-limit-braid-holonomy
hints.title: Limit of Braid Holonomy
hints.content:
823: :label: prop-limit-braid-holonomy
824: 
825: As $N \to \infty$, the holonomy distribution for braided loops concentrates on the identity:
826: 
827: $$
828: \lim_{N \to \infty} \mathbb{P}(\text{Hol}(\gamma) = \sigma) = \delta_{\sigma, e}
829: $$
830: 
831: for any fixed closed loop $\gamma$ in configuration space.

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-171
hints.content:
835: 
836: :::{prf:proof}
837: **Informal argument:**
838: 
839: 1. A braid involves a **finite number** of particles (say $k$ particles exchange positions).
840: 
841: 2. The probability that exactly $k$ specific particles out of $N$ participate in a given braiding event is $\sim 1 / \binom{N}{k} \sim N^{-k}$.
842: 
843: 3. As $N \to \infty$, this probability vanishes.
844: 
845: 4. The mean-field density "sees" only **local averages** - the discrete permutation structure is washed out.
